div1.head: Letter from George Miller Sternberg to the Adjutant General, October 19, 1900
div1.opener:
Communications on official business should be addressed “To the Surgeon General, U. S. Army, Washington, D. C.”
Subject: Detail of delegate to American Public Health Ass'n.
In reply refer to No.
WAR DEPARTMENT.
Surgeon General's Office,
Washington, October [unclear]19th, 1900.
To the
ADJUTANT GENERAL OF THE ARMY.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to recommend that Major Walter Reed, Surgeon
U.S. Army, Curator Army Medical Museum, Surgeon General's Office,
now in this city, be detailed as a delegate to represent the Medical Department of
the Army at the meeting of the American Public Health Association
to be held at Indianapolis, Indiana, from October 22 to 26, 1900.

Major Reed has an important communication to make with refer-
ence to his recent researches relating to the cause and prevention
of yellow fever; upon completion of this duty to return to this
city.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, G.M. Sternberg Surgeon General, U.S. Army.

W H C

div1.head: Special Orders #246, October 19, 1900
div1.p: TO BE RETAINED WITH PAPERS

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 246. }

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, October 19, 1900.
Extract.

25. By direction of the Secretary of War, Major Walter
Reed, surgeon, U. S. Army, now in this city, is detailed to
represent the Medical Department of the Army at the meeting
of the American Public Health Association, to be held at In-
dianapolis, Indiana, October 22 to 26, 1900. Major Reed will
proceed to Indianapolis. Indiana, in time to reach there on or
before October 22, 1900, and upon the adjournment of the as-
sociation will return to his proper station. The travel en-
joined is necessary for the public service.
BY COMMAND OF LIEUTENANT GENERAL MILES:

H. C. CORBIN,
Adjutant General.
